body:
The last index is needed if we have a list of consequent same test module tests to run, e.g.:

python run_test.py -i autograd cuda **torch.TestTorch.test_acos torch.TestTorch.test_tan torch.TestTorch.test_add** utils -f cuda -l torch

Initially ```selected_tests``` will look like this ```['autograd', 'cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add', 'utils']```. When ```options.first``` is processed it will return an index of 1 and ```selected_tests``` will be updated to ```['cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add', 'utils']```. After ```options.last``` is processed it should find the last index of the torch* tests which will be 3 in this case and the result should be ```['cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add']```

I don't think this scenario should be very common as **-f** and **-l** more likely to be used to specify subset of the default tests and not be used together with -i where now we can specify multiple tests part of the same test module but it's good to support such behaviour.
body_html:
The last index is needed if we have a list of consequent same test module tests to run, e.g.:

python run_test.py -i autograd cuda torch.TestTorch.test_acos torch.TestTorch.test_tan torch.TestTorch.test_add utils -f cuda -l torch

Initially selected_tests will look like this ['autograd', 'cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add', 'utils']. When options.first is processed it will return an index of 1 and selected_tests will be updated to ['cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add', 'utils']. After options.last is processed it should find the last index of the torch* tests which will be 3 in this case and the result should be ['cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add']

I don't think this scenario should be very common as -f and -l more likely to be used to specify subset of the default tests and not be used together with -i where now we can specify multiple tests part of the same test module but it's good to support such behaviour.
body_text:
The last index is needed if we have a list of consequent same test module tests to run, e.g.:
python run_test.py -i autograd cuda torch.TestTorch.test_acos torch.TestTorch.test_tan torch.TestTorch.test_add utils -f cuda -l torch
Initially selected_tests will look like this ['autograd', 'cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add', 'utils']. When options.first is processed it will return an index of 1 and selected_tests will be updated to ['cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add', 'utils']. After options.last is processed it should find the last index of the torch* tests which will be 3 in this case and the result should be ['cuda', 'torch.TestTorch.test_acos', 'torch.TestTorch.test_tan', 'torch.TestTorch.test_add']
I don't think this scenario should be very common as -f and -l more likely to be used to specify subset of the default tests and not be used together with -i where now we can specify multiple tests part of the same test module but it's good to support such behaviour.
